content.question:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

The graph below illustrates the distribution of plant and animal species along a <math alttext="20 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> transect along a rocky beach in an intertidal zone. To collect the data, scientists set out a <math alttext="20 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> transect line from the highest high tide point (<math alttext="0 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) out into the Atlantic Ocean. A quadrat was used to collect data between every <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> meter section along the transect and the relative abundance of the species was measured. Wrack is a type of seaweed.

(a) Based on the information in the graph, identify which plant species has the largest range of ecological tolerance.

frqParts.text:
Write your answers in the spaces provided. Refer to the figure or diagram to answer the question. Where explanation or discussion is required, support your answers with relevant information and/or specific examples.

The graph below illustrates the distribution of plant and animal species along a <math alttext="20 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> transect along a rocky beach in an intertidal zone. To collect the data, scientists set out a <math alttext="20 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>20</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> transect line from the highest high tide point (<math alttext="0 meters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) out into the Atlantic Ocean. A quadrat was used to collect data between every <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> meter section along the transect and the relative abundance of the species was measured. Wrack is a type of seaweed.

(a) Based on the information in the graph, identify which plant species has the largest range of ecological tolerance.
(b) Based on the information in the graph, identify the animal species most likely to compete for resources in low tide regions.
(c) Based on the information in the graph, identify the sampling range with the greatest diversity of animal species.
(d) A species of intertidal plant has thick, shiny leaves that reflect sunlight. Make a claim about which area of the intertidal zone this plant is best adapted to live in.

(e) Oceans can provide many ecosystem services. A conservation group wants to improve their local marine area. Describe a government action they could advocate for that would improve a specific marine provisioning ecosystem service.
(f) Marine ecosystems provide different ways to harness resources and generate electricity. Identify and describe electricity generation by harnessing ocean cycles.
(g) Describe one benefit of using the energy source mentioned in part (f) rather than fossil fuels to generate electricity.

Another way someone could reduce their ecological footprint is to think carefully about the type of materials used in their home to reduce energy waste by the windows. Buildings often gain or lose heat through windows. The heat gain or loss in <math alttext="B T U" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BTU</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> per hour can be investigated. To collect the data tabulated below, the inside and outside temperature difference was measured, inserted into a heat gain or loss formula, and converted into <math alttext="B T Us" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BTUs</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Temperature differences were assumed to be constant year-round.

Window
 Surface Area <math alttext="open parenthesis square feet close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>ft</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 Inside and outside temperature Difference <math alttext="open parenthesis degrees Fahrenheit close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mi>°</mi><mtext>F)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 Heat gain or loss <math alttext="open parenthesis B T U per hour close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(BTU/hour)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 Heat gain or loss <math alttext="open parenthesis B T U per year close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(BTU/year)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Single pane
 <math alttext="31" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>31</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="23.9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>23.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="569.9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>569.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="4,992,324" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>4</mn><mtext>,992</mtext><mtext>,324</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Double pane
 <math alttext="31" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>31</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="23.9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>23.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="370" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>370</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="3,241,200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mtext>,241</mtext><mtext>,200</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

Single pane <math alttext="open parenthesis surface area divided by 2 close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(</mtext><mfrac><mrow><mtext>surface area</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mtext>)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="15.5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>15.5</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="23.9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>23.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="284.9" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>284.9</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="2,495,724" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mtext>,495</mtext><mtext>,724</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(h) Identify a constant for the investigation.
(i) Identify the hypothesis of the investigation.

(j) Building design, such as roof color, can affect heat gain or loss. Identify the best roof color for a building located around <math alttext="23" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>23</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> degrees latitude in the Southern Hemisphere and explain why the identified roof color should be used in the building design.

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Describe environmental concepts and processes.
